titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the
Contest responses to Lenore Skenazy's
"Only in New York" and "New York Stories" columns,
New York Daily News,
1988-1995
MS 3232
titlestmt.author: Joseph Ditta (July 2023)

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 15:48:51 -0400.

did.unittitle: Contest responses to Lenore Skenazy's "Only in New York" and "New York Stories" columns, New York Daily News
did.abstract: Submissions by readers of the New York Daily News to weekly contests run in Lenore Skenazy's "Only in New York" and "New York Stories" Sunday magazine columns, in which they answered questions designed to elicit entertaining responses that could only happen to true New Yorkers.
did.physloc: This collection is stored offsite. To arrange to consult it, please go to www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
did.langmaterial: The documents in this collection are in English.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is stored offsite. To arrange to consult it, please go to www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The collection is organized in two series:
Series I. "Only in New York" contest responses, 1988-1990
Series II. "New York Stories" contest responses, 1992-1995

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Although perhaps best know for her then-controversial New York Sun article, "Why I Let My 9-Year-Old Ride the Subway Alone" (2008), subsequent book, "Free Range Kids: How to Raise Safe, Self-Reliant Children (Without Going Nuts With Worry)" (2009), and her activism for the "free-range parenting" movement, Lenore Skenazy has had a long career in journalism. Before moving to the short-lived New York Sun (folded 2008), Skenazy was for fourteen years a regular contributor to the New York Daily News, where her byline headed the "Only in New York" and "New York Stories" Sunday magazine columns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The collection should be cited as: Contest responses to Lenore Skenazy's "Only in New York" and "New York Stories" columns, New York Daily News, MS 3232, New-York Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Archivist Joseph Ditta created this finding aid in July 2023.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Note that the New-York Historical Society does not hold the New York Daily News for the time period covered by the present collection, 1988-1995. The paper has been digitized, and is accessible via the subscription site Newspapers.com.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of letters—some typed, most handwritten, and some on postcards—submitted by readers of the New York Daily News hoping to win one of the weekly contests run in Lenore Skenazy's "Only in New York" and "New York Stories" columns in the Sunday magazine section. The "Only in New York" contests ran from 1988 through at least 1990; the "New York Stories" contests from 1991 or 1992 through 1995 or later. Each week Skenazy posed a question (some of them reworked from previous contests) in which readers were asked to describe the most disappointing thing to have happened on a vacation, or the most creative way they tortured a sibling (or vice versa), or the strangest thing they witnessed at a funeral, or the wildest pickup line they ever used or heard. (See the container list for the complete questions for the entries in the collection; note that the collection is incomplete.) From the most entertaining submissions Skenazy published first, second, and third place winners. In addition to the pleasure of seeing their words in print, winners could expect to receive a "Handsome Keepsake Contest Winner's Plaque" (for "Only in New York") or a t-shirt with the column title printed on it (for "New York Stories).

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff. Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282. Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: www.nyhistory.org/rights-and-reproductions.

controlaccess.subject: Contests.
Journalists.
Newspapers -- Sections, columns, etc.
controlaccess.geogname: New York (N.Y.) -- Social life and customs -- 20th century.

did.unittitle: Series I. "Only in New York" contest responses

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection remains in its original folders, which were marked by Lenore Skenazy with their contest number and an abbreviated and/or paraphrased version of the contest question posed. The container list includes the verbatim questions as recorded in the Daily News, followed by the date the results of each contest were published. "ONY" before each file name stands for "Only in New York."

did.unittitle: Tear sheets and photocopies of published "Only in New York" contests (scattered)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
• ONY Contest 2. {How do you choose your lottery numbers?} [results published September 4, 1988]
• ONY Contest 11. What was the most bizarre thing you ever witnessed on New York public transportation? [results published November 6, 1988]
• ONY Contest 16. What's the one thing about holidays, apart from crowds, we mean, that makes you craziest? [results published December 11, 1988]
• ONY Contest 23. How did your mom and dad meet? [results published February 5, 1989]
• ONY Contest 25. A genuinely appropriate New York fortune cookie fortune. [results published February 19, 1989]
• ONY Contest 31. What's your favorite New York cockroach story? [results published April 16, 1989]
• ONY Contest 33. What was your worst experience with a rude New York salesperson? [results published April 30, 1989]
• ONY Contest 40. The most incredibly annoying colleague you've ever dealt with. [results published June 18, 1989]
• ONY Contest 46. What would you like to find when (and if) you get to heaven? [results published July 30, 1989]
• ONY Contest 54. What was the most useless and irrelevant piece of advice your nice old grandparents ever gave you? [results published September 24, 1989]
• ONY Contest 61. What was the most traumatic thing that happened to you in elementary school? [results published November 12, 1989]
• ONY Contest 63. The stranger you never thanked. [results published November 26, 1989]
• ONY Contest 71. What was the best time you ever had at Rockefeller Center? [results published January 28, 1990]
• ONY Contest 73. How did your sweetie propose? [results published February 11, 1990]
• ONY Contest 82. Your most obnoxious customer. [results published April 22, 1990]

Series II. "New York Stories" contest responses

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection remains in its original folders, which were marked by Lenore Skenazy with their contest number and an abbreviated and/or paraphrased version of the contest question posed. The container list includes the verbatim questions as recorded in the Daily News, followed by the date the results of each contest were published. "NYS" before each file name stands for "New York Stories."

did.unittitle: Tear sheets and photocopies of published "New York Stories" contests (scattered)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
• NYS Contest 19. The least relaxing vacation you ever endured! [results published March 22, 1992]
• NYS Contest 25. Proof that your pet is a genius (or at least pretty darn clever). [results published May 3, 1992]
• NYS Contest 27. What's the silliest thing you ever said in another language—accidentally, of course? [results published May 17, 1992]
• NYS Contest 34. What's the strangest thing you ever witnessed at one of New York's parks or beaches? [results published July 5, 1992]
• NYS Contest 37. What character did you play in make-believe? And what was the basic scenario? [results published July 26, 1992]
• NYS Contest 38. What's the wildest thing you ever did when you came face to face with a celebrity? [results published August 2, 1992]
